Description: Part of a limestone slab (four fragments re-joined), probably from a trial-piece, with regular grids of slighlty different scale incised on both of the flat faces (squares of 2,05 to 2,1 cm on one face, 1,77 cm on the other face). The incised lines of the grid of smaller scale show traces of red colour. One side of the object is preserved, showing a narrow border between the grid and the chamfered edges. The border is wider on the side of the grid of larger scale. EA 23815 (1887,0101.840) is probably a further fragment of the same item, but does not present any joint with it.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, Provenance unclear : Saite enclosure (so-called "Camp") or a room of one of the casemate-buildings of the "Qasr"? Findspot 52 W (west?), domestic buildings in the urban area to the east of the Saite enclosure (so-called "Camp")?
Curator's comments: The item corresponds well to one of the "many pieces of designing tablets of limestone ruled in squares" mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 74 § 70 as "found in the camp and in a chamber of the fort". The mark "52 W" pencilled on the item indicates a provenance from Findspot 52 (west?), south-eastern quarter of the Saite enclosure (so-called "Camp"), area of ironsmith's workshops.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 74 § 70) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.58, p.179, pl.21)
